To Sask. - April, 1892

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person submitting his questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience; others may be impossible for you to answer, so don't worry if they seem to you to be irrelevant. If there is something in particular that you would like to say about your experiences, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for separate questionnaires.

Other Questionnaires:

Western Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here (X).

Western Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaire:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
Wilson, Mrs. Annie F.
Roognville.

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have it written, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your discretion, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name ... Mrs. Annie F. Wilson
2. Your address ... Rouynville, Ont.
3. Date ... April 1959
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Ontario, Canada
5. What was your father's name and occupation? George Wilson
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) April 1899
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? You do not need to answer this question if you are under 18 years of age.
9. What were your reasons for coming West? To earn a living.
10. How did you learn about the West? Through advertisements in newspapers.

I answered an advertisement in a newspaper.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They were opposed to my coming.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)? I traveled by myself.

13. What means of transportation did you use? I came on the C.P.R. to Moose Jaw, from there by train and homestead cutter with a neighbor from a nearby district.

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

I remember distinctly nothing off the train at Moose Jaw at about 8 a.m., and inquiring if there was anyone from Regina district to meet me. A Mr. Smith then editor of "The World Spectator," a former teacher and his wife took me to Queen's Hotel for the night. He found a ride for me to Regina next day. I think he was Mr. Smith afterwards a member of parliament.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

I boarded at the house of Mr. Smith.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

I went back to Ontario the first winter returning in spring.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I was a teacher and I taught school for two summers in Regina district. School was closed in the winter then.

I was a teacher and I taught school for two summers in Preeceville district. School was closed in the winter then. I went back to Ontario the first winter returning in spring.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1916? What reasons did they have for moving?

35. Did anyone move away during 1916? If so, why?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I was secretary for our Mormon Missionary Society of the Baptist church for two years about 1916.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "firsts" to have or do something in the district, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give (1) origin and meaning of the name; (2) date of its adoption; (3) date and reason for change. Give facts of her name or after its first victory.

Our school district was named after Mr. Brown and the town was called after Mr. Brown's son. The first post office was called Brownville; the first school was called Brownville and our district is still Brownville. Our first school was built in the province. It is 3½ miles from the town.
35. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Juras auxiliary for our Moravian Missionary Society of the Presbyterian church for two years about 1916.

36. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

37. If you or any of your family or friends were first to have or do something in the district mention it here, giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to state if the name was given at the time of settlement, or if there were any changes in names since then. Give date and reason for change. Use only one line for each place name.

Our school district was named after Mr. Roan and the town was called after Mr. Roan Bastin; the first Post master so Roanville; the first school was called Roanville No. 2; one of our district is still Roanville No. 2; one of the first schools in the province; the school is 3½ miles from the town.
